record.title: Sha'ir musuh Kelantan [microform] : sebuah naskah asli, diselenggarakan dengan pengenalan dan anotasi / oleh Kassim bin Ahmad.
record.note: Includes index.

record.title: Československý jazyk : Doudlebské nářečí / Pelán Bedřich.
record.note: Holograph (photocopy) signed.

record.title: CIA research reports, Africa, 1946-1976 [microform].
record.note: "A microfilm project of University Publications of America, Inc."

record.title: Compendium musices : theoretico-practicum : das ist, kurtzer Begriff derer nöthingsten Compositions Regeln / abgefasset von Johann Adolph Scheibe ; Ao. 1736.
record.note: Copyist's ms. (possibly that of C. Graupner), in ink.
A ms. with the same title is to be found in the Leipzig Städt Musikbibliothek. Cf. MGG, v. 11, col. 1618.

record.title: Compendium musices [microform]: theoretico-practicum : das ist, kurtzer Begriff derer nöthingsten Compositions Regeln / abgefasset von Johann Adolph Scheibe ; Ao. 1736.
record.note: Copyist's ms. (possibly that of C. Graupner), in ink.
A ms. with the same title is to be found in the Leipzig Städt Musikbibliothek. Cf. MGG, v. 11, col. 1618.

record.title: [Letters] 1672-1679, [Venice, to Johann Friedrich, Herzog von Hannover] [microform] / Antonio Sartorio.
record.note: Sixteen holographs, signed.
In Italian.

record.title: [Missal de Saint-Denis] [microform].
record.note: Ms.
The music is in French neumes.
Detailed description in: Les sacramentaires et les missels manuscrits / V. Leroquais. Paris, 1924.

record.title: John Hill Brinton's notes on cases : 1861.
record.note: Manuscript is written in ink and pencil and bound in full cloth; it was purchased by Dr. Harvey Cushing in December, 1938 from Samuel Mayerman (Philadelphia book dealer).

Includes fragmentary manuscript notes of about fifty casualities under Brinton's care in 1861; his sketches of wounds are included. Pages 1-56 are hand-numbered and preceded by a table of contents. Cushing manuscript #16.

record.title: Chef doeuvre de chirurgie : contenant XIV actes d'examen, tant sur le chapitre singulier, que sur l'anathomie en general, les playes, ulceres, thumeurs, fractures, dislocations, & generalement toutes les maladies appartenantes á la chirurgie / par le Sr. Bonot.
record.note: Manuscript, written in ink and bound in full leather, has title page lettered in red and black. It was purchased by the Yale Medical Historical Library from Thiebaud, catalog 81, in May, 1961.

record.title: Jansenist manuscript, 1723-1744 (inclusive).
record.note: Title on document: Convulsionnaires.

record.title: Notes on general medicine : manuscript.
record.note: Title assigned by cataloger.
Colophon on first and last pages: Joannes Colhoun propria exarauit dextra in insula Rheana anno domini millesimo sexcentesimo quinquagesimo secundi; and: Johannes Colhoun, 8 December 1652.
Place of production: in insula Rheana?
Binding: bound in vellum (manuscript waste). Original text is French, unidentified.

record.title: Elisha Perkins letter and account book, 1788-1816 (inclusive)
record.note: The last 44 leaves are devoted to the accounts of the estate of Elisha Perkins with Sally and Harry Perkins, executors.

The 1st 2 pages of this are written on, but not numbered; then follow 64 pages numbered by hand; the last 11 pages are blank; the last 11 pages are blank; p.23-32 ruled, but otherwise blank; entries are not in order throughout.

record.title: Medical school lecture notes, 1710
record.note: Manuscript, written in ink on paper and bound in contemporary cardboard, was purchased by Yale Med from Thiébaud (Paris book dealer) catalog 85 in 1963.

record.title: Trattato delle lussationi e fratture : manuscript / di Bernardino Genga da Mondolfo.
record.note: Title from title page.
Lightly decorated: first page contains an annotated drawing of a skeleton; middle of the manuscript has a drawing of a leaf.
Binding: limp vellum.

record.title: Cours de médecine.
record.note: Manuscript, written in ink and bound in vellum, was purchased from Thiébaud catalog 85 in December, 1963.
Entitled, "Cours de médicine" with chapters on external diseases of the head, internal disorders, consumption, fevers, and diseases of children. The author of the manuscript is unknown.

record.title: Icelandic sagas : manuscript.
record.note: Manuscript note on first page: "6 May 1806".
Binding: Red velvet over boards.

record.title: Mélanges Islandais : manuscript.
record.note: Title from spine.
Binding: 19th century half leather over marbled paper boards; spine with raised bands, compartments with gilt tooled title and monograms of Comte Riant.

record.title: Icelandic sagas : manuscript.
record.note: Text in Icelandic.
Binding: Red velvet over boards.

record.title: Gad Stanley account book : manuscript.
record.note: Pages numbered 61-139. Volume labeled "Account Book no. 3" on front paste-down.
Ownership signature by Cyrus Stanley, Gad Stanley's son, on front paste-down.

record.title: Biographies of the governors of Iceland from 1300 to 1734 : manuscript.
record.note: Binding: Half red morocco leather with marble boards. Spine stamped in gilt: "Jonas Hitardaleusis, Vitae Praefectorum Islandiae".
Binder's stamp on first page: "Dupré".

record.title: S'ensuit le plaid general et coutume, de la cité & balliage de Lausanne ... : manuscript.
record.note: Title from title page.
Spine title: "Le Plaid General".

Title continues: "... Contenu aux antiquités & vieux droits & documents d'icelle cité, revû de nouveau pour memoire future & pour l'usage de la posterité, par les commis de la ditte cité de Lausanne, des 4 paroisses de la Vaux, que de la ville d'Avenche & autres lieux en dépendans, & approuvé par les nobles citoyens bourgeois & com[m]uniers des dits lieux presenté le vingtiéme d'avril mille six cent & treize, par les dits commis, a l'excellence des illustres & magnifiq[ue] seigneurs de la ville & canton de Berne, leurs souverains seigneurs & superieurs, et luës & confirmées en deux cent à Lausanne, le quinziéme de septembre 1618: comme il est écrit à la fin".
Front pastedown inscribed: "Cons. 6: / 1740".
Includes alphabetical index.
Includes five pages of commentary at end.
Binding: Contemporary parchment over boards, with four leather ties.

record.title: Instruction sur la manière de se servis de la lunette contenans un micromètre fait avec des prismes de cristal de roche : manuscript and printed text.
record.note: Title from head of first page.
Signed on verso of leaf 5: "Par Mr. Filibert Torelli".
Second section titled: "Note de Mr. Alexis Rochon sur l'éffet des prismes de cristal de roche dans cette lunette".
Printed table titled: "Table pour l'usage de mon micromètre".

record.title: L'Art d'instrumenter ou de dresser toutes sortes d'actes publics concernant l'office de notaire selon les loix du Paÿs de Vaud : Copié sur un ouvrage fait en 1715 : manuscript.
record.note: Title from title page.
Includes table of contents at end.
Binding: 19th century half-vellum with block-printed paper covered boards; all edges speckled in blue and red paint.

record.title: Le coustumier c'est à diré les loix statuts & coûtumes de la ville et balliage de Lausanne : Contenu aux antiques droits et documents d'icelles reueu de nouveau par les commis tant de la ville et cité de Lausanne, des quatres parroisses de la Vaux, que de la ville d'Avenche, et lieux en dependants approuvé par les nobles citoyens bourgeois et communiers des dits lieux : manuscript.
record.note: Title from title page.
Includes alphabetical table of contents at end.
Colophon inscribed: "Achevè de copié le present plaid general le 19 [Decem]bre 1703 par Jacob Pasteur Citoyen de Geneve & de Lausan[n]e".
Binding: Contemporary full leather; spine with raised bands and gilt tooled ornaments in each compartment.

record.title: Terrier de Chavvirey le Chatel : manuscript.
record.note: Title from spine.

Binding: Contemporary leather over boards; spine with raised bands and leather lettering piece with gold tooling. Manuscript waste with Latin text and notated music is visible where the back pastedown has been damaged.

record.title: Inventaire du Trésor des chartes : manuscript.
record.note: Title from caption on the first page of text in volume I: "Commission pour travailler a l'inventaire du tresor des chartes".

Pagination: volume 1: xxxii, 214 leaves, 24 blank leaves ; volume 2: 218 leaves, 24 blank leaves ; volume 3: 257 leaves, 30 blank leaves ; volume 4: 159 leaves, 33 blank leaves ; volume 5: 225 leaves, 31 blank leaves ; volume 6: 2 unnumbered leaves, 180 leaves, 28 blank leaves.

Volumes are numbered irregularly on spines and title pages. Numbering as follows: Volume 1: spine: VOL I; title page: vol. i. Volume 2: spine: VOL III; title page: vol. vi and vol. iii. Volume 3: spine: VOL IV; title page: vol. iiii. Volume 4: spine: VOL V; title page: vol. v. Volume 5: spine: VOL VI; title page: vol. vi and vol. vii. Volume 6: spine: VOL VII; title page: vol. vii.

Bindings: Contemporary mottled calf; spines with raised bands and gilt tooled ornaments in the compartments. Each spine includes a compartment lettered in gilt with a variation of "INVENTAIRE DES CHARTES DU TRESOR"; and a compartment containing a volume number.
Volume 1, initial blank leaf verso inscribed in a later hand: "Mr. Hebert à Mouy, Oise".
Boxes 1-6 contain volumes 1-6, respectively.

record.title: Dialogues galans, satiriques, mordans, pour égaier la compagnie, : qui s'endort, ou s'ennui, et pour plaire au grand, au petit, a la personne, qui raisonne comme aiant de l'esprit : manuscript.
record.note: Title from title page.
Binding: Contemporary vellum over boards. Spine has evidence of a paper label, now lost.

record.title: Semitic tetrapla of Matthiew : manuscript / A. B. Chapman.
record.note: Title from cover.
Inscribed on inside front cover: "Begun July 1893". Inscribed at foot of final page: "Finished Sept. 7/96".

Binding: Bound in paper wrappers created from folded shipping packaging; the inside of the cover includes Chapman's address in New Haven, Connecticut, along with cancelled postage stamps. The whole later bound within a library binding.

record.title: Grágás : manuscript.
record.note: Binding: 19th century half calf over marbled boards; spine with raised bands, gilt tooled compartments, and two gilt tooled red morocco labels: "Gragas" and "Christin Kettr".
Manuscript note on title page stating that the contents were copied from the Arnamagnæan manuscript collection at the University of Copenhagen.
Includes an index after Grágás section.

record.title: Über lateinischen Stil bei Hofr. Sauppe : manuscript.
record.note: Title from title page.
Pages 147-154 are blank.
Binding: Contemporary half leather over mottled paper boards. Spine with gold tooled lettering: "Sauppe. Über lateinischen Stil".

record.title: Umschauh : gedichte : manuscript.
record.note: Binding: contemporary calf over boards. Spine title: "Kniep. Gedichte, 2."
Title from title page.
Presentation inscription at the top of first page: "Presented to the Yale University Library, New Haven, Conn. by the author Karl Kniep, Newark, N.J., March 1913".

record.title: Georg Friedrich Meyer notebook containing works relating to geometry, surveying, and sundials : manuscript.
record.note: Note on final leaf: "Found in the ruins of a house torn down in the back part of North Carolina about 30 years since, or about AD 1820".

record.title: Einleitung zu den Komoedien des Publius Terentius Afer : Interpretation der Adelphi, Prof. Sauppe, Georgia Augusta : manuscript.
record.note: Title from title page.
Bookbinder's ticket affixed to the recto of the back free endpaper: "Buchbinderei A. Oehlandt Berlin Behren Str 56".

record.title: Lateinisch Grammatik von Professor Hermann Sauppe : manuscript.
record.note: Binding: quarter calf and marbled paper over boards.
Title from title page.

record.title: Il Nuovo Testamento del nostro signore Giesu Christo : in lingua Italiana Toscana-Romana moderna, traduttione nuova, e chiara ... : manuscript / fatta ... da Mattia Cramero ...
record.note: Title from first title page.
Title pages include partial date: "A[nno]. 17--".
Binding: Contemporary half leather over marbled paper boards; spine with raised bands.

record.title: Dialogorum de Trinitate libri duo : De Iusticia regni Christi, capitula quatuor : manuscript / per Michaelem Serveto, aliàs Reves, ab Aragonia Hispanum. Anno MDXXXII.
record.note: Title from title page.

Binding: Contemporary full leather binding, with gilt and possibly silver stamp featuring intricate strapwork, a pair of birds, and a central bust of a classical emperor surmounted by the letters "F I B" on the front and back boards. The front cover is also stamped with a presentation inscription: "Ihro Gnaden, dem Wohlgebohrnen Herrn Frantz Carl von Hollenstein &c. des Heil. Röm. Reichs-Rittern der Röm. Kaiserl. Majestät Raht, und wohlverordneten Ober-Kriegs-Commissario im Hertzogtum Schlesien. Meinem gnädigen Herrn. 1735."

record.title: Collectanea genealogica Suecica : manuscript.
record.note: Title from inscription on front binder's blank recto.

Binding: 19th century full red leather; monogram of le comte Riant surmounted by a crown stamped in gold in the center of the front and back panels; spine with raised bands and gold tooled filets and lettering. Spine title: "Genealogia Sueciae Regum".
No. 1 of 5 items bound together.

record.title: Le Visioni di Santa Brigida di Suuetia : Cauate da i libri delle sue diuine reuelationi : manuscript / Opera di una monaca professa dell' istesso ordine per maggior commodità delle sorelle. A Maria Vergine, et alla istessa santa dedicata.
record.note: Title from first leaf.
Includes table of contents on six leaves at end.
Colophon, leaf 317r.

Binding: Contemporary red leather over wooden boards; front and back covers have blind tooled rules and rolls, with a central figure of a female saint and the letters "M S B G" tooled in gold; spine with raised bands and a blind tooled flower in each compartment; front edge originally had two leather straps with brass clasps, and is now lacking one strap and clasp. Later (19th century?) paper spine label with manuscript inscription: "[illegible] S. Brigid. Cavate dei libri delle sue rivela[tion]. Opera di una monaca della ordine stisso[?] per comodite delle Sorelle 1626".

record.title: Africa in Haiti; a study of survivals and adaptations in the New World, by Louis C. Sudler.
record.note: Typescript.

record.title: A short history of the Old Cambridge Photographic Club. [Microform] By James A. Wells.
record.note: Typescript (carbon copy).

record.title: Memoirs of Madam Maintenon, Mrs. of K. Lewis XIVth of France [microform]
record.note: Ms.
Caption title.

record.title: A catalogue of books, poems, tracts, and small detached pieces printed at the press at Strawberry-Hill belonging to the late Horace Walpole Earl of Orford manuscript / J. Baker, printer, Great Russel Street, Covent Garden.
record.note: Manuscript copy; 'Introduction' neither signed nor dated. Unclear if this is a copy of the printed work, or a copy in Baker's hand.

record.title: French verses in the autograph of Thomas Gray / with translation and a note by Samuel Clegg [18th century].
record.note: Papers formerly laid in suggest that there is a strong possibility that these poems are not Gray's compositions. (M.M. Smith, Index of English Literary Manuscripts, 20 March 1986). These papers identify the stanza labeled "Ballet de la Paix" as the chorus of Baucis et Philemon by Pierre-Charles Roy.
Title from title page.
Table of contents at beginning of mansucript.
Marbled endpapers.
In gilt on spine: Two French Poems. Manuscript of Thomas Gray.
Binding: half red morocco over cloth-covered boards. In gilt on front cover: Two French Poems. Manuscript of Thomas Gray.

record.title: Pedigree showing descent of Lord and Lady Pomfret from King Edward I, circa 1750.
record.note: Note, in 19th century hand, pasted on front flyleaf: From Horace Walpole's letters to Sir Hor. Mann, Sept. 1st, 1750, "I have seen one [a pedigree] infinitely richer and better done, it is for my Lady Pomfret. She and my Lord both descend from King Edward I by his two Queens. The Pedigree is painted in a book; instead of a vulgar genealogical tree, she has devised a pine-apple plant, sprouting out of a basket on which is King Edward's head; on the leaves are all the intermediate arms." v. 2, p. 222. 1857 ed.
Binding: full calf with marble endpapers; elaborately tooled in gilt with the initials "HP" tooled on front cover; new spine.

record.title: A catalogue of the English portraits in the vellum volumes in the Library, 1774, at Strawberry Hill : those marked in the margin D are duplicates, 1774.
record.note: Note on title page: "Phillipps Ms 18494." Also paper label with Phillipps number on spine.
"1115" in ink on front cover.
Original blue paper over limp boards.
Title written in Horace Walpole's hand on spine: "A catalogue of portraits in the library."

With a print tipped in before title page: Strawberry Hill : the seat of the Honourable Horace Walpole / Barrow del. ; Russell sculp. [London] : Publish'd as the act directs by Bellamy & Robarts, Novr. 1791.

Note on front paste down: "Bought this M.S. Catalogue (in the handwriting of Horace Walpole) Lot 1115 in the Print Sale of Horace Walpole's Collection sold by Robins at his Rooms, Piazza's Covent Garden 1842. T. Dodd."

record.title: Journal of the printing-office at Strawberry Hill near Twickenham in Middlesex : manuscript.
record.note: Title from text at head of page 1, in Walpole's hand.

record.title: Letter books containing copies of letters to and from their agents, chiefly in Constantinople, 1632-1661.
record.note: Eight autograph letters signed to Sir. Andrew Rickard laid in v. 1.

record.title: Journal de Madame du Deffand, 1779 July 1-1780 September 10.
record.note: Title from cover.
Final 206 pages blank. Bound in green vellum.
Formerly classed as: 49 2545 II.

record.title: Recueil de lettres choisies de differentes personnes, 1739-1780 / transcribed by Jean-Francois Wiart.
record.note: Bound in vellum.
Includes an index.
Formerly classed as: 49 2545 V.

record.title: Drawings of antiquities, coins, and heraldry, with copies of old records, [1715?]
record.note: Title from Hazen.
Title from spine of case: Martin's commonplace book 1715.
Signed on front pastedown: Tho. Martin de Thetford in agro Norfolcien 1715.
Attributed to Martin by Hazen.
With the bookplates of Horace Walpole (2nd state) on recto of flyleaf and that of Lord Derby, on the verso of the front flyleaf, with shelf mark 91.D.
Binding: Original panelled calf. In a dark brown leather slipcase.

record.title: Common-place book, 1780-1783 / Hor. Walpole.
record.note: Bound with a manuscript transcription, the title-page of which reads, "Horace Walpole, Earl of Orford, His manuscript common-place book, containing anecdotes on art, men, women, and manners.1780-83"

record.title: A commonplace book of verses, stories, characters, letters, etc. etc. : with some particular memoirs of a certain parcel of people, 1740-[1763].
record.note: Bound in vellum.

record.title: Poems and other pieces / by Horace Walpole, youngest son of Sir Robert Walpole, Earl of Orford. [Holograph], 1736-1756.
record.note: 216 pages blank.
Bound in vellum.

record.title: To John Dodd Esq. at Billingbear on the death of Miss Griffin, 1738.
record.note: Transcribed by Horace Walpole, with annotations, in his commonplace book of poems, pp. 9-10.

record.title: An epistle from Florence to Thomas Ashton Esq., tutor to the earl of Plimouth, 1739-1740.
record.note: Transcribed by Horace Walpole, with annotations, in his commonplace book of poems, pp. 11-26.

record.title: Inscription for the neglected column in the place of St. Mark at Florence, [1740].

record.title: To Zelinda, from Florence, [ca. 1740].

Horace Walpole's note : This eclogue was wrote ... as a sequel to Lady Mary Wortley's Six.

record.title: An epitaph : great without titles, good without pretence, 1741.

record.note: First line: O Venus, joy of man and gods.
Transcribed by Horace Walpole in his commonplace book of poems, p. 39.
An imitation of Horace, Odes I, xxx.
Published in William's Works, ed. Jeffery, 1822, i. 234-6 and YWC, v. 37.76.

record.title: Spectator see poor Charles at fifty four, [174-?].

An imitation of Horace, Odes III, xxvi.

Description in prose, transcribed by Horace Walpole's in his commonplace book of poems, pp. 40-2.

record.title: The praises of a poet's life in imitation of the second epode of Horace, 1742.

Published in YWC 18.357-8.

record.note: A satire on Henry Pelham, John Selwyn and Richard Arundel, transcribed by Horace Walpole, with annotations, in his ommonplace book of poems, pp. 123-34.

Satirizes the fashionable practice of sending written messages on the most trivial occasions.
Published in The Museum, April 12, 1746 (no. 2).

record.title: Advertisement of a new book ... The history of good breeding, 1741.
record.note: 2 pages blank.
Transcribed by Horace Walpole, with annotations, in his commonplace book of poems, pp. 145-50.
Published in: The Museum, No. 5, 1746.

record.title: Verses occasioned by a late will, ca. 1746 June 26, 1746.
record.note: Horace Walpole's copy of The London Evening-Post, Tuesday June 24 to Thursday June 26, 1746 (no. 2908). Annotated and laid in his commonplace book of poems, inside back cover.

record.title: Verses occasioned by a late will, 1746.
record.note: Horace Walpole's transcription, with annotations, in his commonplace book of poems, pp. 151-2.
Published in The London Evening Post, June 26, 1746 (no. 2908).
Horace Walpole's copy of the newsprint is laid inside back cover.
Another verse in 6 lines entitled, "To Mr. Pitt on the same occasion" and a paragraph from another. Evening Post are also transcribed, pp. 151-2.

record.title: The beauties : an epistle to Eckardt, the painter, 1746 July.
record.note: Transcribed by Horace Walpole, with annotations, in his commonplace book of poems, pp. 153-60.
Published in the YWC 30. Appendix 4.324-9.
Originally published "without the author's knowledge" in 1746 by M. Cooper.
Photostats of two unidentified copies are filed in the Walpole Mss File.

record.title: Epilogue to Tamerlane on the suppression of the rebellion by the battle of Culloden spoken by Mrs. Pritchard in the character of the comic muse, 1746 November 4.
record.note: Transcription by Horace Walpole, with annotations, in his commonplace book of poems, pp. 159-62.
Horace Walpole's note: It was printed the next day by Dodsley, and afterwards by him in the second volume of his Collection of Poems.

record.title: Imitation of Lucan (Lib. 1 v. 32) : addressed to Mr. Pitt, 1746 October.
record.note: Transcribed by Horace Walpole, with annotations, in his commonplace book of poems, pp. 163-6.

record.title: A parallel of Sir Robert Walpole and Mr. Pelham, 1747.
record.note: 2 pages blank.
Horace Walpole's note: This has been inserted by the author with some slight alterations in the Memoires of the year 1751.
Transcribed by Horace Walpole, with annotations in his commonplace book of poems, pp. 165-72.
Published in Memoirs of King George II, 1985 ed. John Brooke, i. 153-7.

record.title: A letter to the Right Honorable Lady Caroline Fox, 1748.
record.note: Transcribed by Horace Walpole, with annotations, in his commonplace book of poems, pp. 171-4.
Published in The World, January 1757. Also in YWC 30. Appendix 6, entitled "Walpole's character of Henry Fox, 1748."

record.title: Mac-Hack-Shock-Knock-O-Thunder-Blood : late king of the Mohocks to Richard Rigby, 1748.
record.note: Transcribed by Horace Walpole, with annotations, in his commonplace book of poems, pp. 175-6.
Published in YWC 30. Appendix 5: Walpole's letter from the King of the Mohocks to Richard Rigby.

record.title: Verses on the fireworks for the peace, 1749.
record.note: Transcribed by Horace Walpole, with annotations, in his commonplace book of poems, pp. 177-8.

record.title: Speech in the House of Commons for an address to the king, 17 January 1751.
record.note: Transcribed by Horace Walpole, with annotations, in his commonplace book of poems, pp. 179-84.
Published in Memoirs of King George II, 1985, ed. John Brooke, iii, Appendix 4.154-8.

record.title: Epigram on Admiral Vernon presiding over the herring fishery, [1750].
record.note: Transcribed by Horace Walpole, in his commonplace book of poems, p. 180.
Published in Horace Walpole's Works i. 30.

record.title: Epigram, 1750.
record.note: First line: When Whitfield preaches and when Whiston writes.
Transcribed by Horace Walpole in his commonplace book of poems, p. 180.
Published in YWC 20.134.

record.title: The funeral of the lioness : a fable imitated from La Fontaine, 1751.
record.note: Transcribed by Horace Walpole, with annotations, in his commonplace book of poems, pp. 185-8.
Published in Horace Walpole's Works, 1798, iv. 377-80.
Photostat of a copy in the Merritt Collection at Harvard is filed in Horace Walpole Mss. Verse.

record.title: The World : [contributions in] nos. 6, 8, 10, 14, 28, 1753.
record.note: Transcribed by Horace Walpole, with annotations, in his commonplace book of poems, pp. 189-218.

Includes: no. 6, 8 Feb. 1753, on the theatre; no. 8, 22 Feb 1753, on theodore, Prince of Corsica; no. 10, 8 Mar 1753, on festivals and holidays; no. 14, 5 Apr 1753, on letter-writing; and no. 28, 12 Jul 1753, on loving older women.

record.title: The judgment of Solomon, 1753 November.
record.note: 2 pages blank.
Transcribed by Horace Walpole, with annotations, in his commonplace book of poems, pp. 218-22.

record.title: The entail : a fable, 1754 July.
record.note: Transcribed by Horace Walpole, with annotations, in his commonplace book of poems, pp. 221-4.
Published in Horace Walpole's Works, 1798, i. 28-9.

record.title: The World : [contributions in] no. 103, 1754 December.
record.note: Transcribed by Horace Walpole, with annotations, in his commonplace book of poems, pp. 225-32.
Published in The World, Dec 19, 1754, on the politeness of a nation, and Horace Walpole robbed by James Maclaine.

record.title: The World : [contributions in] nos. 160 and 195, 1756.
record.note: Includes no. 160, Jan 22, 1756 on licentiousness and no. 195, Sep 23, 1756 on suicide.

record.title: Of the miraculous Hamshire oak (extract of a Ms marginal note in Dr. Brown's Enquiries into vulgar errors, p. 100, by Dr. Wren). [Manuscript in an unknown hand], 1735.
record.note: The ms. includes notes on an oak at Malwood Castle and the hawthorn tree at Glastonbury.

record.title: Memoires of the rebellion in 1745, or, A review of the transactions that preceded it and contributed to its rise, [1746?].
record.note: Tipped in Horace Walpole's commonplace book of poems, following p. 245.
Contains notes on the Jacobite rebellion.
Another note on Jacoites is mounted on p. 248.

record.title: Some memoirs of public affairs from the Declaration of the war with Spain ..., [1746?].
record.note: Scrap, fragment.
Tipped in Horace Walpole's commonplace book of poems, p. 248.

Contains Horace Walpole's notes for his Memoirs for the Declaration of the War with Spain which was published in Horace Walpole's Memoirs of King George II, ed. John Brooke, 1985, iii. Appendix 1, pp. 123-39.

record.title: Letter to Horace Walpole / Mrs. Porter, [1738?].
record.note: Dated conjecturally by the reference to the 'ingenious paper' which may have been, as Toynbee suggests, the 'essay' on Mrs Porter as Clytemnestra in James Thomson's Agamemnon, referred to in Thomas Gray to Horace Walpole 23 Feb. 1738 (GRAY i. 151 and n. 2). Mrs Porter played Clytemnestra at the first performance of Agamemnon 6 April 1738 at Drury Lane (London Stage Pt III, ii. 710). Walpole had apparently written to Gray on the subject while the play was in rehearsal. Address: To the Honourable Horace Walpole.
Printed in Yale Edition of Horace Walpole's Correspondence, v. 40, p. 27.

record.title: Old England, or, The Constitutional Journal, or, The Broadbottom Journal : Saturday, June 18, 1743 (no. 20).
record.note: Includes: The Dear witches by Horace Walpole.
Inscribed: This belongs to George's Coffee House Temple Barr.

record.title: Political papers [1747-1753] / written by Horace Walpole ... [Holograph]
record.note: A commonplace book, bound in vellum.
With the armorial bookplate of William Frederick, 9th earl Waldegrave.
Fifteen of the papers were printed in Old England, three in the Remembrancer.

record.title: For mixing of colours ... all ye colours used in a face ... for hair ... for linnen ... for behind heads ... [ca. 1737].
record.note: In Horace Walpole's commonplace book of political papers, at the end of the volume. Hand identified by Wilmarth Sheldon Lewis in a note inside front cover.
Handwriting identified by Wilmarth Sheldon Lewis.

record.title: Mr. Fig's receipt for ye biting of a mad dog, [ca. 1737]
record.note: In Horace Walpole's commonplace book of political papers, fifth page from the end. Hand identified by Wilmarth Sheldon Lewis in a note inside front cover.
Handwriting identified by Wilmarth Sheldon Lewis.

record.title: An explanation of several of Mr. Hogarth's prints, 1785.

record.title: A catalogue of books, poems, tracts, and small detached pieces printed at the press at Strawberry-Hill, belonging to the late Horace Walpole, Earl of Orford [circa 1811].
record.note: Title from title page.
Written on cover: A Catalogue of the Books &c Printed at Strawberry Hill.

Written on cover in another hand: Written by Mrs Damer to whom Horace Walpole left Strawberry Hill. These marked & were sold at Hodson's by her descendant April 30, 1902. Of those unmarked she inherited no copy. This catalogue was written in 1810.
Binding: paper, stitched.

record.title: Memoranda for additions to Lord Orford's Anecdotes of painting in England / H.E., 1822.
record.note: Pasted inside front cover: advertisement for Byfield & Son, booksellers & stationers to the royal family.
Title from title page.
Pasted on back flyleaf: information on the provenance of the manuscript.
The copy of Walpole's Anecdotes of Painting, with Musgrave's annotations, is held by the British Museum.
Binding: full parchment. Written on spine: Addns. to Ld. Orfd Anecd. of Paintg.

record.title: Lecture notes on lectures by Joseph Else, [circa 1775].

record.title: [Billhead of Spencer & Co., general retailer in Madras, for purchases made by J.J. Sinclair, 1920].

J.J. Sinclair arrived in India 1877 and was a founding partner in the firm of Sinclair, Murray, & Co. See: The cyclopedia of India (1907-1909).

"You are requested not to pay without a printed receipt. Please to order the drayman to take away the empty cask."
The reverse notes receipt of payment on February 23, 1808.

record.title: [Permit for Thomas Cooper to receive one cask of foreign brandy, 1809]

Cooper Esq., Jermyn Street], to receive [one] casks of foreign [brandy, qty ten] gallons no., as under part of the stock of [goods condemnd], witness my hand this [twenty second] day of [July], 18[09]. This permit to be in force [two hours] for the goods being sent out of [Excise Office] stock & [two hours] more for the same being delivered and received into Mr [Cooper's] stock. [Tho. Ball]. The above goods sent by [coach]."
At head: "No. [25. (illegible) Tho. Ball. Excise Office, Londn. Divn."

Text on either side of engraved image: "Estimates for the equipment of volunteer regiments. Complete outfits for India, China and all parts of the world."

In manuscript: "Mr. Jessie Ashley, joiner, Leek, to J.S. Moss & Son. 1875, July 10 [illegible]. 16/6" At bottom of the page, in a different hand : "We have this day removed all authority from Mr. J. Weston to transact any business on our behalf, therefore please remit this [illegible] direct to Manchester".

record.title: Lichen.
record.note: "Drawings by Mandy Bonnell. Poem by Gabriel Gbadamosi. Box made by Elizabeth Neville. Letterpress by Graham Bignell." Card bears the signature of Mandy Bonnell, in graphite.
"Lichen in puddles and in woods, along the blue green arm of the beech, on the yellow cushion of rocks, under the orange stare of the sun. Gabriel Gbadamosi."
Unique copy.

Issued with three printed cards (on heavy white paper). The first of these bears the title (printed in mottled green-brown ink); the second, two lines of verse by Gabriel Gbadamosi; the third, the names of the artist and collaborators.
The 20 concertina (accordion-fold) booklets are each comprised of 3 panels (75 x 75 mm), with drawings on the front side only.

The head and foot of each of the 20 packets are comprised of slender loops of paper, on which repetitions of the word "lichen" have been printed (inkjet). Some of the packets bear a fine pattern of pin pricks on an inner panel.

Issued in a hand-made box, covered in gray linen. Title printed letterpress on box top (in green-brown ink). The inside of the box is lined with Japanese paper, into which a pattern of dots (of irregular size) has been cut.

record.title: Billheads of Elliston & Cavell, clothiers, Oxford, for clothing purchased by Mrs. Risley, on behalf of the Warneford Asylum.
record.note: "Bot. of Elliston & Cavell, Ltd. drapers & silk mercers, costumiers, nilliners, ladies & children's outfitters, furriers, glovers, hosiers & haberdashers, trousseaux, layettes, Indian & colonial outfits. "Telegraphic address: Ellistons Oxford. Telephone number 181. 7.8.9.10.11 & 12 Magdalen Street, Oxford."
The lithographed billhead features an illustration of Elliston & Cavell's storefront in Oxford. The sheet from 1909 is printed in blue ink.

Bound in original vellum (now heavily soiled) with hemp ties.

record.title: Billhead of James Cracknall, clothier, London, for tailoring provided to Lord Strathallen, 1830.
record.note: "To James Cracknall, breeches maker to His Majesty and their Royal Highnesses, the Dukes of York, Cumberland & Cambridge. 29, Old Bond Street, London."
The client is presumably James Andrew John Lawrence Charles Drummond, 6th Viscount Strathallan (1767-1851)
Billhead features an image of the royal arms of Great Britain, engraved by Sawyer & Son.
Completed in pen and black ink.

record.title: [Billhead of John Roberts, hosier, London, recording purchases by B. Buggin].
record.note: Addressed on reverse: "Mr. B. Buggin. No. 62 One Seagrove Southampton Buildings Chancery Lane".
The engraved billhead, featuring an engraved image of three kings within decorative circular device reads: "Bought of John Roberts, Hosier, at the three Kings in Fenchurch Street. No. 170".
Barrington Buggin of Harper Street, was a ship broker, and owned warehouses on part of the east and west sides of he Fresh Wharf gateway on the south side of Lower Thames Street.
Completed in pen and black ink.

record.title: Billhead of Vouillon & Laure, clothiers, London, for purchases by Mrs. H.H. Creed.
record.note: "Vouillon & Laure, late partners & successors to Maradan Carson & Cie., Brevetés de La Majesté La Reine, Victoria, 12, Princess Street, Hanover Square. Modes, robes, habits de cour, soieries, corsets, plumes, fleurs & rubans."
The engraved billhead features an image of the royal arms of Great Britain.
Completed in pen and black ink.
The client is presumably the wife of Henry Herries Creed.

record.title: List of necessaries for a civilian proceeding to [blank] : furnished by S.W. Silver & Co.
record.note: Lithographed, on light blue paper.

Caption continues: "S.W. Silver & Co. Clothiers, outfitters and contractors, no. 66, 67 & 70 Cornhill, London, and St. George's Crescent, Liverpool (Emigrants fitting out warehouse no. 4 Bishopsgate St. within opposite the London Tavern). The outfit and cabin furniture for the voyage so arranged as to form a supply on arrival".

record.title: Bill for clothes, notions, and fabrics, 1801.
record.note: With the remnants of a red wax seal.

record.title: [Billhead of T.L. Barrett, general warehouseman, Peterborough, for a purchase by Maude K. Kirkby].
record.note: Engraved billhead features an image of the Barrett storefront, by Waterlow & Sons.

"Bought of T.L. Barrett, general warehouseman. Departments: millinery, mantles, costumes, silks, dresses, underclothing, hosiery & gloves, ribbons & laces, family mourning. Departments: carpets, mattings, curtains, bedsteads, household linens, flannels & blankets, calicoes, fancy blinds, paperhangings".
"And at Skegness".
Completed in pen and black ink.

record.title: [Billhead of H.J. Simkin, carver & gilder, London, for the purchase of picture frames by Mr. Stevenson].
record.note: "Dr. to H.J. Simkin, carver & gilder, picture frame maker & artists mount cutter. 113, Upper Street, Islington, N. Opposite St. Mary's Church".
Completed in pen and black ink.
"Prints and drawings carefully mounted".
"All goods must be paid for on or before delivery".

record.title: [Billhead of W. Woods & Son, fancy hardwaremen, London, for equipment purchased by Mr. Treat].
record.note: The engraved billhead features an illustration of the Woods storefront. Engraved by W.H. Leonard, Birmingham.
Completed in pen and black ink.

"Bot. of W. Woods & Son, general fancy hardwaremen, and manufacturers of hooks & eyes, metallic pens, pen holders, pencil cases, ever pointed & Cumberland pencils, metallic holes, snaps, brace belt & stock buckles, elastic wire, steel locks, swivels, &c. chandelier pins, lamp chains, steel rings, buttons, thimbles, castor tops, guard chains, watch keys, &c. &c."
"Warehouse, 76 Newgate Street, London. Manufactory. Newcastle Street. Faringdon St."
"Wholesale & for exportation".
"Palmer's patent metallic candles & lamps".

record.title: [Billhead of Miller & Sons, candle merchants, London].
record.note: The engraved billhead features an image of the royal arms of Great Britain.

"Bought of Miller & Sons (successors to Mr. Glossop). Spermaceti refiners, wax chandlers & oil merchants, 179, Piccadilly, opposite Burlington House, and at their manufactory, 51, Old Compton Street, Soho. Sealing wax, chamber lamps, floating lights, lamp glasses, cottons &c. &c."
Inscribed: "5 per cent disct from the above prices will depend on the quantity ordered" and "Miller-Piccadilly. Pair of candles."
Completed in pen and black ink.

record.title: [Billhead and receipt of Oetzmann & Co., London, for purchase of carpet by R.W. Stevenson].
record.note: Accompanied by a receipt on a separate form, also from Aug 22, 1881. Stevenson pays £5/0/0, leaving a balance of 19/0. Receipt bears a one penny stamp, printed in red and embossed.
Features a wood-engraved illustration of the Oetzmann storefront.
"Bot. of Oetzmann & Co., cabinet makers, upholsterers, bedding manufacturers and house furnishers throughout."

"Patentees & sole vendors compendium mattress Anglo Turkey, Anglo-Persian and Anglo Indian carpets & rugs. Established in 1848. Showrooms: 67, 69, 71, 73, 77 & 79 Hampston Road. Cabinet Factory: Albion Works, Drummond Street. Bedding Factory : Eagle Works, Hampstead Road. London. N.W."
"Departments: Furniture, bedding, carpets, floor cloths, mattings, drapery, blankets & quilts, table linen, sheetings, damasks, furnishing ironmongery, fenders, fire irons."

"Departments: Table cutlery, electro silver plate, lamps & chandeliers, &c., pictures, bronzes, French & English clocks, paper hangings, china & glass, dinner & dessert sets, tea & breakfast services, toilet sets, vases, instres &c., mats & brushers, wood turnery &c."
Completed in pen and black ink.

record.title: [Billhead of Maple & Co., London, for purchases by R.W. Stevenson].
record.note: "Bought of Maple & Co. carpet factors, upholsterers & cabinet manufacturers."
"145, 146, 147, 148, & 149 Tottenham Court Road. 1 to 15 Tottenham Place, 2,3,4,5,6,12,13 & 14 Grafton St., East".
With a wood-engraved illustration of the Maple & Co. storefront by Waterlow & Sons.
Completed in pen and black ink.

record.title: Billhead of Thomas Townend, London hatter, for hats purchased by Charles Byass, 1849.
record.note: "Bought of Thomas Townend, hat manufacturer, 16 & 18 Lime Street. Superior silk and gingham umbrellas. Gentlemens & childrens caps of every description."
Completed in pen and black ink.

record.title: Bill for building expenses.
record.note: In pen and black ink.

record.title: [Billhead recording cloth purchases from Joseph Osborn, linen and woollen draper, Dunstable].
record.note: "Bot. of George Osborn, linen & woollen draper, hosier, hatter and glover." The word "George" has been crossed through and replaced with "Joseph," in pen and black ink.
"Blankets sheetings, carpets, table linens &c., funerals furnished & every description of family mourning."
The will of George Osborn, of Dunstable, is dated 1851.
Completed in graphite.

record.title: [Billhead of Randall Farr & Co., builder, London, for window cleaning provided to Miss Sparling].
record.note: The wood-engraved billhead features an image of the Randall Farr & Co. storefront.
"Dr. to Randall Farr & Co. Builders, decorators, upholsterers and house and estate agents. 7, Cambridge Place, Norfolk Square, W."
"Your favours and recommendations are most respectully solicited."
"Estimates given for general repairs."
Completed in pen and black ink.

record.title: Receipts by John Williams, of White Hill Kiln, for chimney tunnel tiles purchased by Breandveath, of Houghton, 1848.
record.note: Other supplies (not purchased) on the printed form include bricks, coping, paving, pipes, lime, and an assortment of tiles.
Completed in pen and black ink.

record.title: [Billheads of John Vindin, oil & colourman, Knightsbridge for purchases by Mr. Gibbs, 1823].
record.note: "Bought of John Vindin, oil & colourman, no. 21 Knightsbridge (near the Cannon Brewhouse)."
"Colours prepared for painting."
Engraved by "Ash, 96 Boro." (i.e. John Ash).
Completed in pen and black ink.

record.title: [Receipt for drawing and engrossing lycence for Mr Skynnor and Lady].
record.note: "Stephen Skynner, esqr., his bill. 1757 Decemr. [1] Drawing and engrossing lycence for Mr Skynnor and Lady to domise [i.e. demise] his copy hold estate held of the man of Marshalls £-13/4. [2] Stamps and parchment, -2/8. [3] Paid the Lord his fine as receipt, 1/1/-. [Total] £1/7/0."
Payment recorded at bottom: "22d. September 1758, recd. the full contents of this bill, Phil. [?] Martin."
On reverse: "Stephen Skynnor esqr."

record.title: Receipt for taxes paid by Samuel Forester.
record.note: Printed form, completed in black ink.
"London: sold by Coles, Knight, and Dunn, stationers, No. 21, Fleet-Street, for the price of the stamp only. Printed by I. Gold, late Bunney and Gold, Shoe-Lane, London."--Foot of receipt.

record.title: Taxes assessed to William Moody, of Ampthill.
record.note: Printed form, completed in black ink.
"Bedford: Printed and sold by J. Webb."--Foot of receipt.

The assessment includes taxes for "houses and windows" and "inhabited houses." In 1820, taxes assessed total £0/15/4; in 1823, £0/7/4. Other taxable items listed on the bill are: male servants, carriage with 4 wheels, carriage with 2 wheels drawn by 1 horse, carriage drawn by 2 or more horses, taxed carts, riding and carriage horses, other horses and mules, dogs, horse dealer's duty, armoial bearings, hair powder, game certificates.
J. Coleman is listed as tax collector on both receipts; C. Austin is an additional collector on the 1820 receipt.

record.title: [Tax bill for Samuel Staneforth Esqr of Attercliff [illegible] Darnall, dated July 12, 1814]
record.note: Completed in pen and ink.

"No. 10. Affixed taxes, 1st part for the year 1813. Ending 5th April 1814. To [Samuel Staneforth, Esq] of the [Township] of [Attercliff] [illegible] [Darnall]. Your assessment in my duplicate for the present year, delivered to me on the [12] day of [July] under the Acts relating to the Duties of Assessed Taxes amounts to the sum of [£33/19/10] the particulars of which are stated on the back hereof , and the Assessment may be seen at my house as under-mentioned. If you have any cause to appeal against the same you must give notice in writing 28 days after the said [12] day of [July] to the Surveyor or Inspector for this district orf to one of the assessors of the*. The day of appeal is fixed for the [23] day of [August]. Signed: [Wm Marriott] Collector, residing at "Attercliff'".

Verso of tax bill reads: "Wm. Marriott. Attercliff". Taxes for windows, inhabited house duty, horses (own use, to let to hire, race horses), horses & mules, and dogs totalling £33/19/10. Receipt of payment not recorded.
Other taxable items listed on the bill are: male servants or male performs herein described, 2W. car, 4W carr, allowance for children.
"1st part for 1813. Ending April 5th, 1814".

"N.B. These duties are payable by instalments quarterly, viz. the 20th of June, 20th of September, 20th of December, and 20th of March, or within 10 days after; and the full amount for the first half year, if not sooner paid as aforesaid, will be collected or levied on your goods and chatels on the 10t of October, and the full amount for the second half year, if not pad as aforesaid, will be collected or levied in line manner on the 5th of April, or within twenty-one days after those respective periods; in default of distress or payment you will be subject to process for the recovery thereof from the Court of Exchequer with cost; and if you remove from this parish without discharging the taxes due, or leaving sufficient goods whereon distress may be made, you will be liable to a penalty of twenty pounds".

record.title: [Tax bill for C. Johnstone, Paddington, Middlesex, October 4th, 1856]
record.note: Completed in pen and ink.

Tax bill for C. Johnstone, Esq of Paddington, Middlesex totalling £10/9/11. Taxes to be paid include £4/10/0 for house tax, £1/11/6 for 3 male servants, £1/15/0 for 1 carriage with four wheels, £1/1/1 for 2 horses for riding or drawing carriage, £0/6/0 for 1 dog and £1/6/5 for 6 armorial bearings. Other taxable items include carriages with two wheels, hair powder, horse dealer's duty and land tax. Printed on blue paper. "Taxes" written on back.

"Land and assessed taxes, 1856-7-- First Moiety, County of Middlesex. Parish or place Paddington. No. [2418]. Received of Mr. C.. Johnstone, Esq. the [4] day [October] 185[6], the sum of [ten] pounds [nine] shillings and [eleven] pence, for two quarters' taxes due 20th September, 1856, the particulars of which are stated in the margin. [Geo. Reading] Collector".
"Note.-Persons removing the parish or place, without first paying the duties, render themselves liable to a penalty of £20".

record.title: Letter : to Miguel Barbachano y Tarrazo, Yucatan, Mexico, 1846 May 13.
record.note: Letterhead: Ministerio de Relaciones Exteriores, Gobernacion y Policia.
Small blind-stamp in upper left corner reads: Benfield Mexico.

record.title: [Fire insurance policy for Mr. Robert Gibbs, March 1, 1808, from British Fire Office]
record.note: Completed in pen and ink.
Fire insurance policy, with engraved lion at top, for Mr. Robt. Gibbs, 7 Theobalds Road. [Policy] no. 26170 Premium due on £600: "To pay. £1/0/9. Receipt of payment not recorded.
Four pages. Written on last page: "1808. British Fire Office. Letter. Mar. 1, 1808". No. "26170". Mr. [Robt. Gibbs. 7 Theobaldes Road]". British Fire Office.
"Westminster Society for insurance on lives and for granting annuities, No. 429, Strand, and No. 21, Cornhill."--Advertisement p. 3.

"British Fire Office. Strand and Cornhill, March 1, 1808. [Sir], The next annual payment on your policy, no. [2617] becoming due at Lady-Day next, I beg to remind you, that if the same is not paid within fifteen days therefrom, you cannot claim any benefits from the insurance in case of accident. Please bring this letter or the number of your policy when you come to pay the insurance, and if any alteration in the place or property of the insurance, the policy itself. I am, [Sir], your most obedient servant, Robert Skelton, Sec.

record.title: Indenture placing James Harris into the service of Anthony Harison, goldsmith.
record.note: Completed in pen and ink.
Printed indenture, completed in manuscript, placing James Harris into the service of Anthony Harison, goldsmith, for a period of 7 years, in 1798.

"This indenture witnesseth, that [James Harris ...] doth put himself to appentice to [Anthony Harris ...] citizen and goldsmith of London, to learn his art of [Goldsmith] and with him (after the manner of an apprentice) to serve from the day of the date of these presents, unto the full end and term of seven years, from thence next following, to be fully complete and ended ..."

record.title: Letter : to Miguel Barbachano y Tarrazo, Yucatan, Mexico, 1846 July 29.
record.note: Letterhead: Ministerio de Relaciones Exteriores, Gobernacion y Policia.

record.title: [Bill of receipt for the purchase of a sedan chair by W. Murdoch of Madeira, London, 1788]
record.note: Bill for a sedan chair purchased by W. Murdoch from Holmes & Griffin dated May 1st, 1788. The bill is for a sedan chair with green baize cover and all packing and shipping costs to Murdoch in Madeira totalling £39/9/0/. Receipt of payment made to Thomas Gordon on July 29, 1780 recorded on back of bill.
In pen and black ink.

record.title: Billhead of William Hobbs & Sons, Maidstone, for parcelling bags purchased by Honnors Ltd.
record.note: "Bot. of William Hobbs & Sons, Ltd. Wholesale stationers. Account book, envelope, and paper bag manufacturers. Chromolithographers. Engravers & printers. Show card manufacturers, &c. Established 1841."
With an illustration of the Kent Paper Works, Maidstone.
Completed in typescript.

record.title: Billhead of Richard T. Cussons, bookseller and stationer, Hull, for purchases by Mrs. Maister, Wood Hall.
record.note: "To Richard T. Cussons, bookseller and stationer, (successor to Isaac Wilson), 53, Lowgate. Magazines and every other periodical publication procured as soon as published. Bookbinding of every description executed in the best style. An assortment of ledgers, cash and day books, &c. Always on hand, or made to pattern."
Completed in pen and black ink.

record.title: Letter : San Juan Bautista, Tabasco, to Miguel Barbachano y Tarrazo, Yucatán, Mexico, 1846 November 22.
record.note: Letterhead: Gobierno Superior del Estado de Tabasco.

record.title: Billhead of N. Kelly & Son, stationer, for a purchase by Blake.
record.note: "Wholesale and retail paper warehouse; staionery in variety; leather, mill boards, &c. &c. ... General printing establishment, no. 6, South Great George's Street ... Bought of N. Kelly and Son."
Completed in pen and black ink.
The firm of N. Kelly & Son was active in Dublin from 1815. See: A dictionary of members of the Dublin book trade 1550-1800 (p. 336).

record.title: Invoice from John Smith & Robert Hall, London cheesemongers, at [the] Black-boy in Thames Street, 1726 August 4.
record.note: Title devised by cataloger.

record.title: [Fire insurance policy for Mr. Thomas Mason, May 9th, 1891 from the Phœnix Fire Office]
record.note: Completed in pen and ink.

Fire insurance policy, with engraving at top, for Mr. Thomas Mason. £200 policy no. 3489427. Premium due on policy: £0/4/8. Embossed tax stamp: "One penny" at top. Stamp in purple ink: Manchester Branch, also, Lancaster Bank. Preston. H. Dodgson. Agent.
"Established 1782"

Trustees and directors. Joseph William Baxendale, Esq., Walter Bird, Esq., Bristow Bovill, Esq., The Hon. James Byng, John Clutton, Esq., Geoge Arthur Fuller, Esq., Charles Emanuel Goodhart, Esq., The Rt. Hon. Sir John Lubbock, Bt., M.P., F.R.S., Charles Thomas Lucas, Esq., Charles Magnay, Esq., The Hon. Edwin Ponsonby, The Hon. E.B. Portman, M.P., The Right Hon, the Earl of Radnor, Dudley Robert Smith, Esq., William J. Thompson, Esq. John J. Broomfield Esq. (Hon. Director). Auditors: Joseph Francis Lescher, Esq., Thomas Douglas Murray, Edq., Col. Sir Walter George Stirling, Bart. Joint secretaries: William C. Macdonald, Francis B. Macdonald.
"The conditions wherein referred to are as followed-" 1889. E. Couchman & Co., Printers, 14, Throgmorton Street, London"--On back.

"Phœnix Fire Office. 19 Lombard St. and 57, Charing Cross, London. This policy of insurance witnesseth, that [Mr. Thomas Mason, of the Elmes. Longdon near Preston, Lancashire, Bank Manager] hereinafter call the Insured, having paid to the Phœnix Fire Office of London hereinafter called the Company, the sum of [four shillings and eight pence] for insuring against Loss or damage by fire or lighting, as hereinafter mention, the property hereinafter descripting in the several sums following, namely: on household goods, linen, printed books, wearing apparel, plate, watches, clocks, trinkets, wines, liquors, and mathematical and musical instruments [and] on china, glass, and looking=glasses [and] on pictures and prints (no one picture or print, case of loss to be valued at more than £[10]. In [his] private dwelling house, situate as above, Brick=built. [and stated].

[Memo: The person named Thomas Mason is now dead & it has been declared that the Interes law this policy is now vested in his widow Mrs. Jane Mason now residing at a house brick built of late. Known by the name Dryden Schawler at London aforesaid hereaftermore has declared that the property named herein is now [illegible] by this policy. Entered in the office books 20 Sept 1898. Dodgson Fire Agents Preston].

"The Company hereby agrees with the Insured, (but subject to the conditions at the back hereof, which are to be taken as part of this Policy), that if the property above described, or an part thereof, shall be destroyed by fire or lightning, at an time between the [30th April 1891] and the 2th June, 189[2], both inclusive, or at any time afterwards, so loss as the insured or [his] representatives, being successors in interest, shall pay to the company, and it shall accept the sum required for the renewal of this policy, such loss or damage, to an amount not exceeding in respect of the several matters above specified the sum set opposite thereto respectively, and not exceeding in the sum of [two hundred pounds]. In witnesss whereof, one of the Directors of the said Company has hereunto set his hand, the [9th] day of [May 189[1]. Total premium: £0/4/8 to Midsummer, 189[2]. Annual premium: £0/4/8 payable 23th June. [Edwin B. Portman]. Examined, [illegible]

record.title: Land tax bill for William Bourn, April 5th, 1798.
record.note: In pen and ink.

"April the 5. Recd. of [William?] Bourn the sum of sixteen shillings for one years land tax for land leying in Bethersden belonging to Richd. Beal Esq.--up to Lady Day 1798. James Palmar. Collector. Bethersden.
Receipt of payment for land tax of 16 shillings owed by [William?] Bourn for land owned by Richard Beal in Bethersden. Written on back: [Willm?] Bourn. Woodchurch.

record.title: [Advertisement for patent doors, windows, & shutters for the prevention of burglary]
record.note: Probably an advertising circular for Stable & Son, Ironmongers, who are listed at 24 High St., St. Giles' in the Directory of London and Westminster & Borough of Southward, 1794 and Johnstones directory of London, 1817.

Advertisement for metallic window shutters, door & fastenings to aid in the prevention of burglary and fire protection. Engravings of two windows and a door and of the Royal Arms of His Majesty at top of sheet.

"To form a proper estimate of the great advantage and elegant appearance of our improved metallic window, shutters, doors & fastenings for which we have obtained his Majesty's Royal Letters Patent they must be seen in operation as any description which could be incorporated within the limits of a circular would fall indefinitely short in conveying to your mind an adequate idea of he inportance utility and taste, which upon inspection would be found to be associated in these improvements ... 24 High St. St. Giles'. We remain your mos obedt. servts, [Harris & Kitchen]"
"N.B. Models will be forwarded if requested".

record.title: [Advertisement for venetian fan blinds, brass cornice poles spring roller blinds, painted blinds and curtain brackets, London, 1818]
record.note: Barron & Co. is listed at these addresses on p. 28 in the Commercial directory, for 1818-19-20. Manchester : J. Pigot, 1818.
Advertisement for Barron's patent venetian fan blind with six illustrations of different available designs.

"Barron & Co. Patent Venetian Fan Blind. No. 4,5,6, represent Barron & Cos. improved spring bonnet blind. No. 4 is shewn drawn up, no. 5 let down & no. 6 extended. M. Barron has obained a patent for machinery for feeding fire with fuel, his object is chiefly for self-supplying hot houses on an economical & regular principles. Manufatory 72 & 73 Wells Strt. Oxford Srt. London & 25 Lower Temple Strt, Birm."
Price list of reeded rods and window brackets on back along with illustrations of two windows with decorative rods and brackets.

record.title: Bill for school expenses from Hacconby School, for Mr. Bavin : 18th June, 1835.
record.note: "Hacconby School. John Thos. Hebblewhite, has the honor of again returning thanks to his friends for the continued support he has received since his residence at Hacconby, and respectifully solicits their future patronage. Terms known on application at the School. Hacconby, June, 18th, 1834."--Printed exterior of the bill. Printed by William (?) Daniell, Bourne.

Records school expenses for slate, an account book, and pens and ink, with extra for drawing, totallling £1/7/9. Receipt of payment received by J.T. Hebblewhite recorded on Dec. 5, 1835. Written on back: "Mr. Bavin. Rippingdale".
Completed in pen and black ink.

record.title: Bill for school expenses for Mr. Bryans from Miss Thompson, 17 and 18 Holland Road, Brighton.
record.note: Records school expenses for board and instruction, German, music, drawing, dancing and lectures of £20/13/8 with an added charge of £1.4.2 for disbursements totalling £21/17/10. Receipt of payment recorded on April 29, 1889 by Jane Smith for E.M. Thompson.
"The day to return is May 10th. Train from Victoria. 5.47."
Includes a Penny Lilac tax stamp affixed at bottom.
The "Misses Smith" are listed at this address in 1884 in Our schools and colleges / Frederich Shirley Dumaresq de Carteret Bisson.
Completed in pen and black ink.

record.title: Bill for school expenses for Miss Mason at St. Helens School, Clifton, Bristol.
record.note: The primary item (4 pages) records expenses for the second term, 1884 for Miss Mason at St. Helens, The Avenue, Clifton, Bristol. Expenses listed are for music lessons, singing, drawing lessons, riding school, china painting, dancing, sanatorium, lectures, stationery, laundress, seat in church, medical attendance, and tradesmen's bills, totaling £45/10/1. Written on page 2: "The 3rd term 1884 will begin on September 15th." Bill for books on second page totals £0/2/6.
The second item records expenses for Miss Mason, second term 1884, for music lessons totaling £5/8/0.
The third item is for "China and oil painting lessons during term ending July 1884" for "Miss E. Mason" totaling £5/5/0. Written at bottom: "K.L. Blood, July 24th, 1884".
Completed in pen and black ink.
Includes a Penny Lilac tax stamp affixed at bottom.

record.title: Bill for school expenses from Broomfield Hall for Miss Dodson.
record.note: "Broomfield Hall, Kidderminster. Dr. to E.F. Ridley & C.E. Bennett."--Billhead.

Records school expenses for Miss Dodson for board and tuition, piano, solo singing, dancing and calistenics, sheet music, stationery, laundress, entertainments, travelling expenses, boot bill, sundries and library, totaling £24/1/0.5.
"The [Spring] term will commence on [Tuesday, Jan. 30. 1883]. It is particularly requested that all pupils return punctually, and that accounts may be settled on or before the above date."--Leaf [2].
Completed in pen and black ink.

record.title: Bill for school expenses for Miss Kate Lamb, due to Mrs. Blundell at Grey Friars' House, Lincoln.
record.note: Expenses include: board and instruction, French, music, laundress, hairdresser, books, stationery, music pieces, and omnibus, etc., totaling for £14/9/6. Receipt of payment is recorded by Mrs. Blundell on July 8th, 1882.
"The duties of the Establishment will be resumed [Friday May 12th]."--Foot of bill.
Completed in pen and black ink.
Includes a Penny Lilac tax stamp affixed at bottom.

record.title: Bill for school expenses for C. Lamb, to be paid to Edwin R. Dibben, Classical School, Mount Pleasant, Sleaford.
record.note: Includes expenses for board & tuition, washing, mending, pew rent, hair cutting, materials, and sundries totaling £10/19/0. Receipt of payment is recorded on Nov. 15, 1880.
"The School will re-assemble on [Wednesday] the [15th] of [September] 18[80] when punctual attendance is respectfully requested. A quarter's notice is required previous to the removal of a pupil".
Includes a Penny Lilac tax stamp affixed at bottom.
Completed in pen and black ink.

record.title: Bills for school expenses for Miss Gleason, to be paid to Amy Godfreys, Vernon Street, Derby.
record.note: Includes a Penny Lilac tax stamp affixed at bottom.

The first bill, dated Xmas 1878, includes expenses for board and tuition, drawing, calisthenics, dancing, drawing material, lectures, stationery, new books and extras, totaling £16/0/0. With a detailed list of books and extras written on page 3. Receipt of payment is recorded by January 20th, 1879.

The second bill, dated Easter 1879, includes expenses for board and tuition, drawing materials, drawing, calisthenics, dancing, German, lectures, stationery, and new books, totaling £16/13/0. Receipt of payment is recorded on May 6th, 1879.
Completed in pen and black ink.

record.title: Bill for school expenses at King's Lodge Academy, Exeter, to be paid to the Messrs. Quicke.
record.note: Records school expenses of 1/4 year's tuition of Master Head (or Heal?). Expenses include: fire subscription, copy books, pens and ink, use of books, cipher book, grammar, and spelling book, totaling £4/17/3. Receipt of payment is recorded by Thos. Quicke, Nov. 9, 1850.
Includes detailed description of the school's services on pages 2 and 3.
"Spencer, printer, Exeter."--Foot of page [2].
Completed in pen and black ink.

record.title: Bill for school expenses for F. Blanchard at B. Barrett's boarding school, Great Yarmouth.
record.note: Includes expenses for board & tuition, instruction on the violin, copy books, books, pen and ink, waste paper, weekly cash, hair cutting, and shoe and clothing repair, totaling £15/18/9.

"Classical, mathematical, nautical & commercial boarding establishment for young gentlemen, North-Quay House, near the New Bridge, Great Yarmouth Norfolk, conducted by Mr. Barrett, and experienced classical assistants ..."--Page 3.
Completed in pen and black ink.
Billed to Mr. Blanchard, 5 Hackney Terrace, [Illegible] Road, Hackney, London. Stamped in black: Great Yarmouth, Norfolk. June 28, 1847. Postage stamp removed.

record.title: Bill for school expenses for Miss H. Townley at Mrs. Laurie's school, Bath Place, Reading.
record.note: The bill is addressed to the Revd. H. Townley.

Expenses include: tuition, washing, dance, French and geography, writing and arithmetic, pens, ink &c., use of library and seat at chapel, French & English class books, threads, tapes, &c., shoe maker's bill, apothecary's bill, gloves, mantua maker's bill, coach hire, mending shoes, pocket money, hair cutting, soap, pair of scissors, repair of linen, family medicine, and gratuity to servants, totaling £20/4/10. Receipt of payment not recorded.
Completed in pen and black ink.

record.title: Bill for school expenses for Jean Cockburn, at Mrs. Waldie's school, Hendersyde.
record.note: The bill is addressed to J. Weir.
Expenses include: instruction in English and writing, a dictionary, a grammar and vocabulary book, Scott's elocution, paper, pens, and ink, totaling £0/19/6.
A second small sheet (50 x 110 mm), is inscribed: "Mrs. Waldie of Hendersyde."
Completed in pen and black ink.

record.title: Bill for school expenses for Miss Davenport, at H. Boulaye's school, Manchester.
record.note: Expenses include: instruction, writing and accounts, and books, totaling £4/10/6. Receipt of payment not recorded.
Madame Boulaye is listed as a French teacher residing at 11, Charlotte St., Manchester in Pigot & Co's. National commercial directory for 1828-29.
Completed in pen and black ink.

record.title: Bill for school expenses for Cyrill Clough, at Henry Lloyd's school.
record.note: Expenses include: board and tuition to Christmas 1795, books, pocket money, apothecary, dancing master, shoe maker, shoe cleaner, tailor, hair cutter, school fire and cleaning, voluntary contribution to news-paper, sergeant. &c., and usual present to servants, totaling £19/11/6. Receipt of payment recorded by H. Lloyd on Christmas, 1795.

"Mr. Lloyd sends respects to Mr. Clough, and agreeably to his desire, his son's account. The last article in which was omitted thro' haste at Mids. It is hoped that considerable improvement will be observed by Mr. C. Mrs. L. unites in respect to Mr. C. & family."--Page 3.
Completed in pen and black ink.

record.title: Bill for expenses at Grove House School, Highgate.
record.note: Expenses include: "half term's education of son, to July 29, 1892," drilling, drawing, drawing materials and mounts, school cap, two pieces of music, printed books (grammar, geography, history, arithmetic, reader, Latin, French and spelling), totaling £3/6/3. Receipt of payment is not recorded.
The bill is addressed to R. Stevenson, Esq., to be paid to A.E.C. Dickinson.
Completed in pen and black ink.

record.title: Account by Antonio López de Santa Anna of his actions during the Texas Revolution : addressed to the Congress of the Republic of Texas, 1836 October 12.
record.note: Caption title: A los Honorables Señores del Senado y de la Camara de Representantes.
Accompanied by a typescript English translation made by a former owner, dated 6 March 1958.
Disbound; foliated out of order.

record.title: Household account book for Kenmare House, Viscount Kenmare's at Killarney, 1780-1781.
record.note: Binding: Original green vellum. Spine annotated in a contemporary hand.
Written in ink mainly on rectos only.

record.title: [Billhead of Francis M. Herring, chemist].
record.note: "Dr. to Francis M. Herring, dispensing and operative chemist, 33, Bath St., three doors from the post office. The Leamington salts manufactory."
Completed in pen and black ink.

record.title: National Panorama, 21, York Street, Westminster : Battle of Tel el Kebir, by Oliver Pichat.
record.note: "This bill gives free admission for one child, if accompanied by adult".
Printed on pink paper.

The July 7, 1883, issue of The Cardigan Observer and General Advertiser for the Counties of Cardigan Carmarthen and Pembroke notes the visit by the Prince of Wales to the National Panorama, Westminster, to view the work by Pichat.

record.title: [Billhead of A. & R. Thwaites & Co., Dublin].
record.note: "Bot. of A. & R. Thwaites & Co., preparers of soda & other mineral waters, salts, &c. under the sanction of the medical gentlemen. 147 Regent Street, London. 57 Upper Sackville Street, Dublin."
Addressed to "Dr. Verner" (?), and dated "Dublin [June] 185[7]."
"Importers & manufacturers of mineral waters to the Irish court since 1800."

record.title: [Billhead of Reece & Co. for supplies bought by the Medical Botanical Society].
record.note: "Chemical & medical hall, no. 168, Piccadilly. Prescriptions carefully compounded. Chemical reagents for analyses & philosophical experiments. Medicine chests of various descriptions. Adapted to all climates. Chemical and mineralogical chests &c."
"Bought of Reece & Co."
Features an illustration of the Reece & Co. storefront at 168 Piccadilly.
Completed in pen and black ink.

record.title: By Her Majesty's command, Frogmore House & gardens to be shown to Miss Smith & her party.
record.note: An engraved admission ticket completed in manuscript and signed, presumably by a secretary to the Queen.

record.title: An account of the charges for catching the red deer out of the woods of the Rt. Honble. the Earl of Salsbury at Hatfield, from Novre. the 9th, 1734, to February the 2nd 1734/5.
record.note: Title from caption.
Written in pen and and black ink.
A detailed schedule of payments made by Lord Grey, Earl of Tankerville, of Chillingham Castle, for 85 days hunting. With a footnote regarding George Lowen, huntsman.
"Memdm. Mr. Geo. Lowen the huntsman hath taken in Hodsdon [?] Woods from the 25th of Novem. to the 9th Jany. 1734 ... 18 eighteen brace of male deer, 39 thirty nine brace of female deer."

record.title: Martyrology of Usuard.

Binding: white leather over beveled boards. Spine title in a later hand: Martyrolog. d'alia Obituarium...

record.title: Crystal Palace season ticket, 1855.
record.note: Season ticket for admission to Crystal Palace, 1855 ("available till 30 April 1856"). No. 21921, signed by Charles Carrington (the ticket holder). All text is engraved, with printing on both sides, the rules of use on the reverse. In contemporary calf wallet, with blue silk lining.

"This ticket is available till April 1856. It admits the proprietor to the palace and park whenever they are open to the public, but not at other times. The proprietor must sign his name on the face of the ticket before presenting it and also in a book at the door whenever required so to do. The ticket must be shewn whenever he enters the palace and when asked for by the savants of the Crystal Palace Company. If presented by another than the person who signed it it will be forfeited. Ticket lost cannot be replaced. The bearer of this ticket is bound to observe all the rules made from time to time by the directors for the regulation of visitors."--Verso.

record.title: [Printed invoice and promotional handbill of Hafod Arms Hotel].
record.note: The hotel was originally a small hunting lodge built in 1787 by Thomas Johnes, the then squire of The Hafod Mansion Estate, and it was enlarged and converted into a Swiss style chateau in 1839 by the third Duke of Newcastle, and Sir Henry Houghton. It attracted numerous visitors and inspired the Wordsworth poem "To the torrent at Devil's Bridge".
The invoice features an engraved illustration of Devil's Bridge.

"This Hotel is erected amidst the wildest and most magnificent scenery, on a precipice contiguous to the Devil's Bridge, commanding a view of the Grand Cataract of the Rhydol, and within hearing of the tumultous Fall of the Mynach. Distance from the Hafod 5 miles ; from the Ruins of Strataflorida Abbey 9 ; from Aberystwith 12 ; from London 199 miles."
"Height of the Cataracts. From the bridge to the water, 114 feet ; first fall, 18 feet ; second 60 ; third 20, Grand Cataract 110 feet ; total from the bridge to the bed of the river, 322 feet."
"Visitors may be accommodated with a Guide."
Completed in pen and black ink.

record.title: South English legendary.

record.title: Emendatio vitae and other works.

record.title: [Verse and prose in Latin and Middle English].

record.title: Statuta vetera.
record.note: Part of the Anthony Taussig Collection of English Legal Manuscripts (OSB MSS 184).Taussig catalog number: MS 81.7.14 (number 3 in main catalog numbering).
A complete description of the contents is found in Baker and Taussig, Catalogue (London: 2007), pp. 4-7.
Layout: single column, 16-19 lines.
Script: contemporary Anglicana hand.
Decoration: Initials mostly in blue or burnished gold; 23 larger initials in burnished gold on red and blue grounds. One large illuminated initial with ivy-leaf border including a dragon.
Binding: contemporary stitching on three double bands; later vellum over pasteboard binding.

record.title: The establishment of the yearly charge of our dyett, with incidents for housekeeping : also wages & boardwages to the officers & servants of our house, chamber, chappells, & stables, with provisions for horses : also allowances, stipends, and pentions to old & supernumerary servants and widows, to commence the first day of October, 1714.
record.note: Includes a detailed table of contents at front.
Cover title: Civil list establishments &c.
Written in pen and black ink throughout; on ledgers ruled in red.
Bound in 18th century parchment.

record.title: De legibus et consuetudinibus Angliæ.
record.note: Part of the Anthony Taussig Collection of English Legal Manuscripts (OSB MSS 184). Taussig catalog number: MS 82.12.7 (number 19 in main catalog numbering).
A fuller description of the contents is found in Baker and Taussig, Catalogue (London: 2007), pp. 13-14.
Title from incipit.
Some early marginalia. Lengthy annotation in Law French (ff. 182v-183) concerning a dictum by "Denam" (probably John or William de Denum).
Annotated on f. 1 in the hand of Sir Thomas Phillipps: H. Bracton De Legibus Angliæ. From Sir G. P. Turner's Library. Phillipps MS 3097.
Layout: double columns, 32 lines.
Script: Gothic Textura.
Decoration: headings, paragraph marks, and running titles in red or blue; two-line initials throughout in red and blue; two large initials in red and blue.
Binding: nineteenth-century full russia, blind-stamped. Gilt title on spine: Bracton De Legibus Angliæ.

record.title: Natura brevium and other works.
record.note: Part of the Anthony Taussig Collection of English Legal Manuscripts (OSB MSS 184). Taussig catalog number: MS 86.6.25 (number 69 in main catalog numbering).
A fuller description of the contents is found in Baker and Taussig, Catalogue (London: 2007), pp. 33-34.
Script: English book hands.
Decoration: initials have red and blue flourishing; many paragraph marks in red or blue.
Binding: late eighteenth-century? full brown morocco, gilt. Title on spine: Fitzherbert Natura Brevium. Codex MSS in membranis.

record.title: Presentation album to Abraham Follett Osler, on his eightieth birthday : illuminated with miniatures.

record.title: Treatise on artillery.

record.title: Index to the works of Hogarth in 3 vols. folio, ca. 1799 November.

Another note following the above on page [8]: N.B. These composed the collection which Mr. Steevens gave by his will to Mr. Windham and were valued by Mr. Thane for the legacy duty at £600.

record.title: Falconer Madan collection of Oxford manuscripts, circa 1680-1929.

record.title: A plan of mathematical learning taught in the Royal Academy, Portsmouth : performed by a student there 177[blank].

record.title: Genealogies of the kings of England.

record.title: Papal bull.

Lead seal attached by cord.

record.title: An inventory of the household furniture, china & glass of Edw. Williams Esqr. at his dwelling house at Tingrith in Bedfordshire, 1772 May 20.

record.title: Translation of the Diamond sutra and the Sukhavati sutra into Chinese, 1792.

record.title: Ledger with returns of subsistence stores to Fort Grant, Arizona, 1889 July-1890 November.

record.title: Letter concerning trade in the Missouri and Illinois regions, circa 1794.

record.title: Letter, to Lord Chancellor Clarendon, 1663 : manuscript.

The letter is written on one piece of paper and is folded in two.

record.title: Notes on the colors and arrangement of Gilbert Stuart's palette, circa 1850.

record.title: Commonplace book, [circa 1750-1780].

record.title: Catalogue of Bradenham House library, Norfolk, [1807-1833].

record.title: Compendium historiae in genealogia Christi.
record.note: Format: seven membranes sewn together to form one roll.
Layout: single vertical column in the form of a genealogical tree.
Script: single gothic bookhand.

Decoration: text is presented as a genealogical tree, in brown ink, with rubrication; initials in red and blue ink; roundels and planned spaces for diagrams and miniatures (unfinished) outlined in red and blue ink. Linking genealogical tree branches and diagram lines in red and blue ink. Complex grid for layout of design elements ruled in plummet.
Ownership inscriptions at top and bottom of roll: Conradus Mondone Astensis. (Corrado Mondone d'Asti, Master General of the Dominican Order, 1462-1465).

record.title: The beginning of a commonplace book, 1957-[1976].

record.title: Honky-tonk Sue : a screenplay, 1985 March / by Larry McMurtry [and] Leslie Marmon Silko.

record.title: The misfits, 1960 March / by Arthur Miller.

record.title: Gradual.
record.note: Script: written in liturgical bookhand. Music in square musical notation on five four-line red staves.
Decoration: five miniatures; eleven large ornamental initials on gold grounds; many decorated initials with penwork.
Miniatures have been attributed to the Olivetan Master and the Master of the Lodi Choir Books.
Binding: full deerskin over wooden boards; extensive metalwork on binding.

record.title: Single entry day book, 1794.

record.title: Glossary list, [circa 1750].

record.title: Funeral sermon on Psalm 119:92, 1744 September 20.
record.note: Signed on the last page: "St. Ervan. Sept. 20th 1744. N. Hoskins."

record.title: [Britton].
record.note: A fuller description of the contents is found in Baker and Taussig, Catalogue (London: 2007), p 10.
Decoration: headings and paragraph marks in red or blue; some initials in red or blue. One large initial "P" at the beginning of Book IV (f. 21v.). Model arbor consanguinitatis on f. 46v.
Several leaves cut away (stubs not included in present collation).

record.title: Letter portfolio owned by Marie-Caroline de Bourbon-Sicile, Duchesse de Berry, [1800s].

record.title: Memorandum of recognizance for Robin Manchester, 1720 February 9.
